## Can we predict crime rates? {background-color="#E8F4F8"}

::: {.columns style="font-size: 0.85em;"}
::: {.column width="80%"}
::: {.fragment}
### The Challenge
:::

::: {.fragment}
Predict crime rates for each Mexican state **ahead of time**

**Approach:** State-year predictions

- **Training:** 2011-2015 data
- **Prediction:** 2016-2018 outcomes
:::
:::

::: {.column width="80%"}
::: {.fragment}
### The Method: LASSO regression
:::

::: {.incremental style="font-size: 0.9em;"}
1. **Input:** Crime rates and socio-economic variables
2. **Process:** Identify important predictors
3. **Output:** Predictions with key factors 
4. **Validation:** Compare predictions to actual outcomes
:::
:::
:::

## How LASSO Works {background-color="#E8F4F8"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Data Structure

**Dependent variable:**
- Crime rate (what we predict)

**Independent variables:**
- Economic indicators
- Past crime patterns (lags)
- Demographic factors
- Geographic features
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Model Selection

::: {.fragment}
**Alpha parameter** controls how many predictors to keep
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Optimization:** Minimize prediction errors (Mean Residual Sum of Squares)
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Result:** Sparse model with only important factors
:::
:::
:::

## Model Performance {background-color="#E8F4F8"}

::: {.fragment style="font-size: 0.75em;"}
**How the model performs:** Model explains **92% of variation** in crime rates
:::

::: {.columns style="font-size: 0.8em;"}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### What This Means

::: {.incremental style="font-size: 0.9em;"}
- This means strong predictive capability
- Reliable for policy planning
- Many crime patterns are systematic, not random
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Limitations

::: {.incremental style="font-size: 0.9em;"}
- State-level only (not municipality)
- Historical patterns may change
- We need consistent data collection over time
:::
:::
:::

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="33%"}
### Geographic Patterns

::: {.fragment}

::: {.fragment}

:::

::: {.column width="33%"}
### Crime Type Patterns

::: {.fragment}
**Non-violent:**
- Common theft (most frequent)
:::

::: {.fragment}
**Violent:**
- Homicide (most frequent)
:::
:::

::: {.column width="33%"}
### Predictive Factors

::: {.fragment}
**Key insight:**
Each crime type has **different determinants**
:::

::: {.fragment}
There is no "single size fits all" model
:::
:::
:::


## Policy Implications

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Integrated Approach 

::: {.incremental}
- Target impunity to disrupt criminal operations
- Focus resources on main drug trafficking hubs
- Consider cross-border dynamics (U.S.-Mexico)
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### Predictive Analytics Value

::: {.incremental}
- Enable **proactive** interventions
- Understand better the crime-specific factors
- Design targeted policies by crime type
:::
:::
:::

## Conclusions

::: {.r-fit-text}
Data + Analytics = Better Policy
:::

::: {.incremental}
- Illicit markets produce many predictable patterns (not all)
- Violence concentrates in specific locations (border states and some central regions)
- Systemic impunity undermines civic trust
- Predictive models can help more effective public safety interventions
- Each crime type needs a tailored approach (there is not a single suit for all)
:::
